| Food item (typical serving) | Approx. weight | How many 100‑g equivalents? | Visual cue |
|-----------------------------|----------------|----------------------------|------------|
| **Two slices of deli turkey or ham** (≈ 30 g each) | ~60 g | 0.6 × 100 g | A stack of two standard‑thickness lunch‑meat slices on a plate |
| **Two slices of bacon** (≈ 15 g each) | ~30 g | 0.3 × 100 g | A short strip of bacon about the length of a matchbox |
| **One hot‑dog sausage** (standard beef/pork dog) | ~45 g | 0.45 × 100 g | One “classic” hot‑dog in a bun |
| **One slice of pre‑cooked salami** (≈ 25 g) | ~25 g | 0.25 × 100 g | A thin slice the size of a playing‑card |
| **One pork or beef “bacon” (Canadian “peameal” bacon) strip** | ~30 g | 0.3 × 100 g | One thick strip, about the width of a thumb |
| **One 2‑inch‑wide, 4‑inch‑long chicken‑style “nugget” or “tender” that has been cured/ smoked** | ~25 g | 0.25 × 100 g | Roughly the size of a small matchbox |

**Putting it together:**  
- **A typical “breakfast” of two slices of ham + two slices of bacon** = ~90 g of processed meat (≈ 0.9 × the 100‑g benchmark).  
- **One lunch‑meat sandwich with 4 slices of turkey** = ~120 g (≈ 1.2 ×).  
- **A single hot‑dog** = ~45 g (≈ 0.45 ×).  

So, **one 100‑g “portion” is roughly the amount you’d get from a modestly sized sandwich filling, a couple of slices of cured lunch meat, or a half‑to‑three‑quarter‑size hot‑dog.**  

> **Why the 100‑g figure matters**  
> The dose‑response curves in the major meta‑analyses (e.g., WCRF/AICR 2020) are often expressed per **100 g/day** of processed meat.  That does **not** mean you must eat exactly 100 g every day; it is a statistical unit.  The risk rises roughly linearly, so cutting the average intake from 100 g to 50 g per day halves the incremental risk associated with processed meat.
